Walker Howe, What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America, 1815-1848

Animating Questions/Argument:

Howe's animating question is, pretty much: what hath God wrought?

Howe's interpretation of the early nineteenth century is the Whig side of Sean's Democrat coin. In other words, Howe sees the Whig party as one of aspirations and reformers â€“ the party of the future. Above all, however, Howe sees technology and communication as the most essential causes for transformation in this period, driving what some call the market revolution, though he doesn't really buy that. He does not see this era as one of widespread democratization in the political sphere so much as he sees it in society - through activism and religion.

Samuel Morse and suffragists are Howe's emblems of the transformations of this period.
